description: Combine rows from two or more tables based on a related column.

slides.title: Why Join? üîó
slides.content:
# Relational Data

Data is often split across multiple tables to avoid duplication (Normalization).

**Joins** allow you to query data from multiple tables as if they were one.

slides.title: INNER JOIN
slides.content:
# The Default ü§ù

Returns records that have matching values in **BOTH** tables.

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
SELECT users.name, orders.amount
FROM users
INNER JOIN orders ON users.id = orders.user_id;
FULL_CODE_END -->

If a user has no orders, they won't appear.

slides.title: LEFT JOIN
slides.content:
# All From Left ‚¨ÖÔ∏è

Returns all records from the left table, and matched records from the right.

If no match, the right side will be NULL.

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
SELECT users.name, orders.amount
FROM users
LEFT JOIN orders ON users.id = orders.user_id;
FULL_CODE_END -->

Users with no orders will appear with NULL amount.

slides.title: RIGHT JOIN
slides.content:
# All From Right ‚û°Ô∏è

Returns all records from the right table, and matched records from the left.

Exact opposite of LEFT JOIN.

slides.title: FULL OUTER JOIN
slides.content:
# Everything üåê

Returns all records when there is a match in **EITHER** left or right table.

Note: MySQL does not support FULL OUTER JOIN directly (use UNION). PostgreSQL does.

slides.title: Join Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which JOIN returns all rows from the first table, even if there are no matches in the second table?

slides.title: CROSS JOIN
slides.content:
# Cartesian Product ‚úñÔ∏è

Returns all possible combinations of rows from both tables.

If Table A has 10 rows and Table B has 5 rows, result is 50 rows.

Usually not what you want unless generating combinations.

slides.title: Self Join
slides.content:
# Me, Myself & I ü™û

A regular join, but the table is joined with itself.

Use aliases to distinguish the two instances.

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
SELECT A.name as Employee, B.name as Manager
FROM employees A, employees B
WHERE A.manager_id = B.id;
FULL_CODE_END -->

slides.title: Multiple Joins
slides.content:
# Chaining ‚õìÔ∏è

You can chain multiple joins.

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
SELECT *
FROM users
JOIN orders ON users.id = orders.user_id
JOIN items ON orders.id = items.order_id;
FULL_CODE_END -->

slides.title: Aliases
slides.content:
# Short Names üè∑Ô∏è

Use `AS` to make queries readable.

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
SELECT u.name, o.date
FROM users AS u
JOIN orders AS o ON u.id = o.user_id;
FULL_CODE_END -->

slides.title: UNION
slides.content:
# Stacking Results ü•û

Combines the result-set of two or more SELECT statements.

Columns must match.

`SELECT city FROM suppliers UNION SELECT city FROM customers;`

slides.title: Type Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: What is the result of a CROSS JOIN between a table with 5 rows and a table with 4 rows?

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Joins üîó

Connect your data.

- **INNER:** Matches only.
- **LEFT:** All left + matches.
- **FULL:** Everything.
- **CROSS:** All combinations.
